advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You hesitate between two standards."<br> "Rank Xerox doesn't."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual floppy drive version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advertisement from a UK Sage dealer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The European Alternative'' ! <br><br> The Basis 108 was sold in France by BMI. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV FEB. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECOND 6502</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Second Processor option features, in a separate case, a 3 MHz 6502 processor and 64 KB of RAM. It was connected to the BBC system through the Tube channel. The BBC RAM was then used as video RAM, so the full memory area of the Second Processor was available for user programs.<br> Two ROMs was also delivered. The first one holded a new BASIC version called HI-BASIC that made full use of the new memory configuration. The other updated disc or Econet filling system.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for Victornet, the net for Victor computers, based on Omninet.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I met Apple IIc" <br><br> French advert from MAJUSCULE distributor.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Compatible with you know who.<br> Equiped like nobody.<br> Priced like Amstrad".<br> <br> Single drive, monochrome monitor = 4997 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, monochrome monitor = 6290 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, colour monitor = 6890 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, colour monitor = 8190 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, monochrome monitor = 9990 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, colour monitor = 11890 FF + VAT</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>DEC Advertises its range of networking products.<p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new Laser 3000" <br><br> "At last, un complete PRO system with disk drive for 4980 F"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil 3: three micro-computers in one!"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD MOTHER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

computer.description:
The main improvement over the other PET / CBM computers is the 80-column display. The screen is 12'' large and the ROM version is 4.0.
The CBM-80xx was often sold as a "bundle". It was made up of the computer (most often the CBM 8032, though other models were made), the 5.25" double disk drive CBM 8050 (500 KB, 77 tracks) and the bi-directional 132-columns, 160 CPS printer. The 8050 has a 6502 CPU, 4 KB of RAM and 12 KB of ROM (which contains the DOS). It was sold with Ozz, a Database, and a version of the spreadsheet "Visicalc". _______________________

item.description: Clock/Calendar module||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOCK/CALENDAR MODULE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Could be connected to any PET/CBM user port. Clock and calendar were battery backed up.</blockquote>
Eprom programmer||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> EPROM PROGRAMMER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Could burn 2716 and 2732 Eprom chips.</blockquote>

TNW-2000|||IEEE-488 to Serial converter|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> TNW-2000</strong></font><br><strong>> IEEE-488 to Serial converter</strong><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Pascal Rollin</b></p></blockquote>

Dual disk-drives|||Model 2040|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DUAL DISK-DRIVES</strong></font><br><strong>> Model 2040</strong><br><blockquote>This dual 5.25" floppy disk is single sided, double density and has a storage capacity of 170 Kb per disk, or 360k total. It's connected to the computer through an IEEE-488 interface and uses CBM DOS 1.0. </blockquote>

8050 dual disk-drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8050 DUAL DISK-DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>CBM PET Model 8050 Dual disk drive. It uses a 100 TPI single headed drive with a storage capacity of 533,248 bytes per drive. Each 8050 disk has 77 tracks, and is read/write compatible with the model 8250 disk. This compatibility is limited to one side of the diskette. <br><br> It can be used with Commodore Series 2001, Series 3000, Series 4000 and Series 8000. It uses an IEEE-488 interface.</blockquote>

8250-LP dual drive unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8250-LP DUAL DRIVE UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8250-LP (for Low Profile) uses dual half-size double-side, double-density 1 MB capacity floppy drives. The main logic board is entirely different from the full-size 8250. It uses two 6502 processors!</blockquote>

9090 Hard-disk||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 9090 HARD-DISK</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a single drive non-removeable Winchester technology storage device. It features 3 platters with recording surfaces on both sides and provides 7.5 million characters of storage. A single random access file may occupy the entire capacity. It has an IEEE interface connector and a "slow blow" fuse on the back.</blockquote>
8023P COMMODORE TRACTOR PRINTER ||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8023P COMMODORE TRACTOR PRINTER </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.name: CBM 80xx

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 8032 SK</strong></font><br><blockquote>The CBM 8032-SK was also sold in a European version called <b>PET 200</b>. Character generator ROM and keyboard were modified to fit the system to various European languages. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CBM 8296</strong></font><br><blockquote>This version holds 128 KB of RAM<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Roman von Wartburg</b> from Germany</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HAMSTER CAGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This monitor found a new job as a hamster cage in the department's mechanical workshop of the University of Amsterdam!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://www.science.uva.nl/faculteit/museum/" target="_blank">University of Amsterdam </a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
